Description: Terracotta amulet-mould in Nile clay; two deep grooves marked through edge of mould down to level of bottom of impression, so the amulet produced from this mould would be pierced lengthwise; impression of a simplified version of wedjat eye inscribed in a rectangle; outer edge of impression is oval; would have formed right eye when moulded; remains of pale yellow paste/glaze inside; in red brown micaceous Nile silt fabric.
Curator's comments: In addition to glazed composition scarabs and scaraboids, the ‘Scarab Factory’ at Naukratis was also producing amulets (on the various productions from the Scarab Factory see Webb, forthcoming; see also Gorton 1996, 177-180, fig. 35). Petrie listed a number of amulet-moulds including moulds for wedjat eyes of different types (Petrie 1886, 37, pl. XXXVIII, 16-17). This specimen could be from the Scarab Factory. Almost identical mould for wedjat eye BM 1920.0417.1, BM 1896,0610.31 and Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-E.4573 made from same master. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OJ.03) (phase 2)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 17) (almost identical cast from such mould)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2016, 19 May-27 Nov, BM exhibition Sunken Treasures
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (on behalf of)
